description: Seven Minutes That Shook the Convention - POLITICO Magazine
'It's always been there for us': a love letter to New York's fire hydrants | US news | The Guardian
extended: The quintessential tradition has remained intact throughout decades of change, but with gentrification taking hold, are these the scenes of a dying New York? Edwin Canela sits outside, on a white chair on a north Manhattan sidewalk, with an old boombox to his right, and a mini barbecue to his left.

description: How the Real Hackers Behind Mr. Robot Get It So Right | WIRED
extended: This week on the premiere of Mr. Robot, the hacktivist collective fsociety made good on its threat to bring down the evil E Corp.

In Why I Love, PC Gamer writers pick an aspect of PC gaming that they love and write about why it's brilliant. Today, Phil explains why Uplink is the best depiction of hacking in gaming. Films and TV shows have a patchy history when it comes to the accurate depiction of technology and computing.

description: bellingcat - "We've shot four people. Everything's fine." The Turkish Coup through the Eyes of its Plotters - bellingcat
extended: A group of plotters of the failed Turkish coup attempt used a WhatsApp group to communicate with each other.

description: Ta-Nehisi Coates on the Near Certainty of Anti-Police Violence - The Atlantic
extended: By ignoring illegitimate policing, America has also failed to address the danger this illegitimacy poses to those who must do the policing. Last month, the Obama administration accused Donald Trump of undercutting American legitimacy in the eyes of the world.

description: If You Laughed At The Tronc Job Ad, Read This — Medium
extended: When TRONC posted a job for a ‘content specialist’ last week, future-of-news-watchers and journalists at large lost their collective minds. Cue media Twitter freakout and mass derision, most apparent from people who didn’t seem to understand the role—check out a sample of the hilarity here.

Follow along with our coverage of the Democratic National Convention. WASHINGTON — An unusual question is capturing the attention of cyberspecialists, Russia experts and Democratic Party leaders in Philadelphia: Is Vladimir V. Putin trying to meddle in the American presidential election?
